summary: An in-depth interview with Jocelyn Bell Burnell that explores her journey in astrophysics, her discoveries, and the challenges and triumphs of women in science.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a dark screen that transitions to a logo featuring a circular emblem with the text "INSTITUTO DE ASTROFÍSICA DE CANARIAS" encircling a starry design, set against a backdrop of red and blue gears. The word "VOCES" appears prominently in the center. The scene then shifts to a close-up of a person with short, curly hair and glasses, identified by on-screen text as "JOCELYN BELL BURNELL," a "Discoverer of first pulsars" and "Visiting Professor of Astrophysics, University of Oxford." The background shows a bookshelf filled with books, suggesting an academic setting. The person is seen speaking, with subtitles in Spanish translating to "They are really a family, with different subgroups, and the magnetars seem to be one of the subgroups of pulsars." The video maintains a focus on the individual, emphasizing their role in astrophysics and their discussion on pulsars and magnetars.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a steady, pulsing electronic music track, suggestive of a science fiction theme. The music is rhythmic and constant, evoking a sense of tension or intrigue. Suddenly, a female speaker begins to talk about pulsars, defining them as families with subgroups, mentioning magnetars as one of those subgroups. She speaks in a calm and informative tone.  Her monologue ends and the electronic music continues, maintaining its previous mood and characteristics.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a woman wearing glasses and a white jacket, sitting in front of a bookshelf filled with various books. She appears to be speaking, and subtitles in Spanish appear at the bottom of the screen, translating to "But they differ from most pulsars in 2 aspects:" and "First, they do not emit pulses in the radio range, normally they are silent in radio." The scene then transitions to an animated depiction of a pulsar, with a bright central object surrounded by blue and purple lines representing magnetic fields. The subtitles continue, stating "They are strong in the X-ray range." and "The other reason why they are different is that they have exceptionally large magnetic fields." The video maintains a focus on the pulsar's magnetic field structure, emphasizing its unique characteristics.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a single female speaker explaining that they "don't do radio pulses" and are typically "silent usually in the radio." She continues to explain that they are strong in the x-ray and also have "exceptionally large magnetic fields," with a calm, informative tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a woman with short gray hair and glasses, wearing a white coat, speaking in a library setting surrounded by bookshelves filled with various books. She discusses the magnetic fields of pulsars, with subtitles in Spanish providing context to her speech. The subtitles translate to "The other reason they are different is that they have exceptionally large magnetic fields," "A typical pulsar has magnetic fields of about a hundred million Tesla," and "But in magnetars they are even larger, a thousand times larger than in a typical pulsar." The scene transitions to a visual representation of a pulsar, depicted as a glowing sphere with blue and purple magnetic field lines extending outward. The subtitles continue, explaining that "then the magnetic fields are very, very strong," and "Probably, the magnetic fields are responsible for the emission of X-rays." The video combines the woman's explanation with visual aids to illustrate the concept of pulsars and their magnetic fields.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single female speaker describing pulsars, stating that they have strong "magnetic fields", and magnetars have fields "thousand times bigger". The speaker notes that "very, very strong magnetic fields" are responsible for "the emission of X-rays".

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a woman in a library, surrounded by bookshelves filled with various books. She is wearing glasses and a beige jacket, and she appears to be reading or studying. The scene transitions to a black-and-white photograph of a young man standing in front of a large array of radio telescopes, with the text in Spanish: 'El radiotelescopio que construí cuando era estudiante de posgrado abarcaba 2 hectáreas,' which translates to 'The radio telescope I built when I was a graduate student covered 2 hectares.' The next frame shows a close-up of a document with text about a woman's academic achievements, accompanied by a black-and-white portrait of the same woman. The text in Spanish reads: 'y te parece muy grande cuando lo estás construyendo tú,' meaning 'and it seems very big to you when you are building it.' The video then shifts to a color image of a modern radio telescope array, with the text: 'Pero cuando llegue el "Square Kilometer Array," podremos ver muchísimo más,' which translates to 'But when the "Square Kilometer Array" arrives, we will be able to see much more.' The final frames show a close-up of the radio telescopes, emphasizing their size and technological advancement.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a female speaker reminiscing about a radio telescope she built, mentioning its large size relative to the Square Kilometer Array. Her tone is slightly humorous, expressing awe at the scale of the project. The speaker states they "will be able to see much, much more." In the background, there is a low, consistent ambient sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a large radio telescope array under a clear blue sky, with the text "En particular, deberíamos poder ver todos los pulsares activos en la galaxia" (In particular, we should be able to see all the active pulsars in the galaxy) displayed at the bottom. The camera then zooms in on the intricate metal framework of the telescopes, highlighting their structure and design. The scene transitions to an indoor setting, where a woman with short hair and glasses, wearing a beige jacket and a patterned scarf, is seated in front of bookshelves filled with books. The text "Actualmente, con los telescopios más grandes que tenemos," (Currently, with the largest telescopes we have) appears at the bottom. The woman appears to be speaking, and the text changes to "podemos ver los pulsares en la mitad más cerca de la galaxia," (we can see the pulsars in the half closest to the galaxy). The video continues with the woman still speaking, and the text changes again to "pero no los que están más lejos," (but not the ones that are farthest away). The video provides a visual and textual exploration of the capabilities of current telescopes in observing pulsars within the galaxy.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single female speaker discussing the visibility of pulsars in our galaxy, noting the current limitations of our telescopes to see only those in the nearer half. Her tone is informative and somewhat technical. The clip contains no music or background sounds.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a sweeping aerial view of a vast landscape dotted with numerous large satellite dishes, set against a backdrop of sparse vegetation and a clear sky. The text on the screen reads, "pero no los que están más lejos," (but not the ones that are farthest away), suggesting a discussion about the limitations of current technology in observing distant objects. The camera then zooms in on the satellite dishes, with the text changing to, "Pero con el 'Square Kilometer Array' deberíamos ver todos los púlsares de la galaxia," (But with the 'Square Kilometer Array' we should see all the pulsars in the galaxy), indicating the potential of a new array to observe pulsars more comprehensively. The scene transitions to a close-up of a person in a library, surrounded by bookshelves filled with various books. The text reads, "y me imagino que algunos púlsares en las galaxias exteriores," (and I imagine some pulsars in the outer galaxies), as the person speaks, likely elaborating on the potential discoveries. The camera then shifts back to the satellite dishes, with the text, "Tendremos además una muestra mucho mejor de púlsares," (We will also have a much better sample of pulsars), emphasizing the improved data collection. The scene returns to the library, where the text reads, "así que podremos entender mejor cómo evolucionaron," (so we will be able to understand better how they evolved), as the person continues to speak, discussing the implications of these findings. The video concludes with the person in the library, with the text, "y cómo las subfamilias/subgrupos están relacionados entre sí," (and how the subfamilies/subgroups are related to each other), highlighting the importance of understanding the relationships between different pulsar groups. The final text reads, "Esto será muy emocionante," (This will be very exciting), as the person expresses enthusiasm about the future discoveries. The video effectively combines aerial views of the satellite dishes with close-ups of the person in the library, creating a narrative that connects technological advancements with scientific exploration and discovery.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a female speaker enthusiastically discussing the potential of a "square kilometer array" to detect pulsars, both within and outside of our galaxy. She anticipates a "much better sample of pulsars," leading to a deeper understanding of their evolution and relationships. The speaker notes excitement at possibly discovering special examples, like "a pulsar in a binary with a black hole."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a captivating depiction of a black hole, surrounded by a swirling accretion disk of glowing gas, with beams of light emanating from its poles. The text on the screen reads, "Encontramos pulsares en binarias con otras estrellas de neutrones," which translates to "We found pulsars in binaries with other neutron stars." The scene transitions to a person in a library, wearing glasses and a beige jacket, speaking about pulsars in binaries with other neutron stars and main sequence stars. The text on the screen changes to "pulsares en binarias con estrellas de secuencia principal," meaning "pulsars in binaries with main sequence stars." The video then returns to the black hole imagery, with the text "pero no pulsar - agujero negro," translating to "but not pulsar - black hole." The narrative continues with the text "Nos encantaría tener algunos de estos," meaning "We would love to have some of these," followed by "porque sería tan extremo en términos de graviación, de gravedad," translating to "because it would be so extreme in terms of gravitation, of gravity." The video concludes with the text "y sería una buena comprobación de la teoría de relatividad de Einstein," meaning "and it would be a good confirmation of Einstein's theory of relativity." The imagery throughout the video emphasizes the extreme gravitational forces and the potential for testing Einstein's theory of relativity.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a female speaker discussing pulsars found in binaries with various objects, such as neutron stars, white dwarfs, and main sequence stars, but notably not with black holes. She expresses a desire to find pulsars in binary systems with black holes, explaining that the gravitational extreme would provide a good check of Einstein's relativity. The audio clip is underpinned by soft, ambient piano music, creating a gentle and contemplative atmosphere throughout the speaker's monologue.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a woman in a library, surrounded by bookshelves filled with various books. She is wearing glasses and a beige jacket, and she appears to be engaged in a discussion about poetry with astronomical themes. The text on the screen is in Spanish, and it translates to "I started collecting poetry with astronomical themes after hearing this poem." The woman is seen flipping through a book, and the text continues to describe the poem's theme, mentioning the vastness of the universe and the concept of time delay. The video includes a black-and-white image of a woman, identified as a British poet named Elizabeth Jennings, and a close-up of a hand holding a book. The text on the screen references the poem's title, "Retraso," and describes the imagery of stars and constellations. The video also features a visual representation of the night sky with constellations and a glowing green comet, accompanied by text that translates to "And the zodiacal constellations." The woman continues to speak, and the text on the screen discusses the delay in time and the brightness of the Sun compared to other stars. The video concludes with an image of a blue sphere representing the extent of humanity's first radio signals, with text that translates to "The impulse of the star has to wait for the eyes to proclaim it beautiful." Throughout the video, the woman's gestures and expressions convey her passion and enthusiasm for the subject matter.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a female speaker announcing that she started collecting poetry with astronomical themes after hearing a particular poem. She mentions it's by a British poet called Elizabeth Jennings and that Jennings is interested in the idea that because stars and galaxies are so distant, it takes light and radio waves a long time to get from there to here. The speaker, in a calm and articulate tone, says she's writing a poem around that point. The poem is called "Delay." She then reads the poem in a gentle, expressive tone. As she finishes reading, gentle, peaceful piano music starts playing.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person, likely a woman based on the visible attire and hairstyle, engaged in a thoughtful activity in a library setting. She is wearing glasses and a light-colored jacket, with a patterned scarf visible around her neck. The background is filled with bookshelves, indicating a scholarly or literary environment. The person is seen interacting with a notebook, flipping through its pages, and then placing a piece of paper on top of it. Subtitles in Spanish appear on the screen, translating to "The root of that short poem," followed by "I have been collecting many poems," and "There is a lot of poetry with Astronomy and Space as a theme." The subtitles suggest that the person is discussing poetry, possibly related to astronomy and space, and is reflecting on her collection of poems. The video captures a moment of intellectual engagement and contemplation within a serene and studious atmosphere.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a female speaker talking about a poem and collecting many poems, noting that there is a lot of poetry with astronomy and space as its theme, speaking in a normal tone. Afterward, the audio abruptly cuts.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person wearing glasses and a light-colored shirt, seated in front of a bookshelf filled with various books. The individual appears to be engaged in a conversation or interview, as indicated by their facial expressions and the presence of subtitles in Spanish. The subtitles discuss the person's interest in the number of women in physics and astrophysics, their experience as a woman holding the most responsible position in all the places they have worked, and their role as a Professor of Physics. The subtitles also mention the doubling of the number of female physics professors in Great Britain over the past 20 years, from one to two, and the current number of physics professors in Great Britain, with approximately 600 of them being women. The setting is an indoor environment, likely a library or study room, with a calm and academic atmosphere. The person's expressions and the subtitles suggest a reflective and informative tone, focusing on gender representation in the field of physics.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a female speaker discussing her interest in the number of women in physics and astrophysics. Her tone is thoughtful and slightly somber as she recounts being "the most senior woman" in her field and humorously notes that she doubled the number of female physics professors in Britain, "from one to two". She then states the statistic that there are now "about 600 professors of physics" and "maybe 50 of those are women" in Britain, remarking that it's a small number but bigger than before. Throughout the entire clip there is a background music that seems to be piano, its tone is somber.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a woman wearing glasses and a beige blazer is seated in a library, surrounded by bookshelves filled with various books. She is engaged in a conversation, gesturing with her hands as she speaks. The subtitles in Spanish appear on the screen, translating to "There are a lot of women studying Astronomy, but more women than men drop out, so at the level of high positions, there are fewer women." The woman continues to speak, and the subtitles change to "Another thing I have done is study the data from other parts of the world." The setting is academic, with the woman appearing to be discussing gender disparities in the field of astronomy. The video captures her expressions and gestures as she elaborates on her points, providing a detailed and informative discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a female speaker discussing astronomy, stating that there are "good numbers of women" studying astronomy, but fewer reach senior positions compared to men. She mentions examining data from around the world. Simultaneously, there's instrumental music, slow and calming, possibly piano-based, creating a reflective atmosphere.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a series of scenes centered around a woman who appears to be a speaker at a conference or seminar. She is seen in various settings, including a library and a stage, where she discusses the representation of women in the field of astronomy, specifically within the International Astronomical Union (IAU). The woman, dressed in a beige blazer and patterned blouse, is shown gesturing as she speaks, emphasizing her points. The text on the screen, in Spanish, translates to "Another thing I have done is study data from other parts of the world," indicating her research focus. The video also includes shots of the audience, who are attentively listening and participating, with some holding up yellow cards, possibly for voting or signaling agreement. The atmosphere is professional and academic, with a focus on the importance of gender diversity in scientific fields. The video transitions between close-ups of the speaker and wider shots of the audience, highlighting the engagement and interest in the topic being discussed.
events_list.audio_caption: A woman speaks in a measured, thoughtful tone, discussing the number of women in the International Astronomical Union, noting that membership requires seniority and nomination, which may contribute to suppressed numbers. Piano music, slow and slightly melancholic, plays softly in the background.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a middle-aged man with glasses, wearing a beige jacket and a patterned shirt, seated in front of a bookshelf filled with various books. He appears to be engaged in a conversation or interview, as indicated by his facial expressions and the presence of subtitles in Spanish. The subtitles provide context to his speech, revealing that he almost became an astronomer but faced challenges, including failing an important exam at the age of 11 in Great Britain. Despite this setback, his parents supported his education, allowing him to pursue a more academic path. The man recounts his educational journey, starting in Northern Ireland and later attending a boarding school. The video maintains a consistent setting, with the bookshelf and the man's attire remaining unchanged throughout the sequence. The subtitles offer a glimpse into the man's personal story, highlighting his perseverance and the influence of his family in shaping his academic aspirations.
events_list.audio_caption: A woman speaks with a measured and thoughtful tone, recounting how she almost didn't become an astronomer. She mentions failing an important exam in Britain, but her parents thought differently and she received more academic schooling, first in Northern Ireland and later at boarding school. She recalls her first week in advanced schooling. Light, soft music plays in the background throughout.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing glasses and a beige shirt, speaking in front of a bookshelf filled with books. He shares his experiences with a more advanced teaching system, mentioning that boys and girls were sent to different places. The scene transitions to a classroom where boys are working on science projects, with a teacher supervising them. The text on the screen reads, "A los chicos les enviaron al laboratorio de ciencias," which translates to "The boys were sent to the science lab." The video then shows a group of girls in white uniforms, presumably learning sewing and cooking, with the text, "Esperaban de nosotras que aprendiéramos a coser, a cocinar, etc." meaning "They expected us to learn to sew, cook, etc." The narrative continues with a scene of a boy and a woman in a salon, where the boy is getting his hair cut. The text states, "Mis padres se enfadaron mucho cuando lo supieron, y protestaron," translating to "My parents were very angry when they found out, and they protested." The video then shows a classroom with a teacher writing on a blackboard, with the text, "y la próxima vez que hubo clase de ciencias, había 3 chicas, y todos los chicos," meaning "and the next time there was a science class, there were 3 girls, and all the boys." The video concludes with the man speaking again, with the text, "Hicimos en este primer curso Física y Astronomía," translating to "We did Physics and Astronomy in this first course." The video provides a glimpse into the man's educational experiences and the gender-segregated teaching practices of the past.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a somber piano melody, setting a reflective mood. A female speaker begins to recount an experience from her first year of school, specifically how the boys and girls were separated into different classes. She narrates how her parents pushed back on this policy and got her into the science class, where she excelled. Her speaking tone is light, with hints of amusement and pride. The piano music fades out and then the speaker concludes the story with a skeptical remark about whether the school learned anything from the incident.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a woman with short hair and glasses, wearing a beige jacket and a red and white patterned shirt, seated in a library surrounded by bookshelves filled with various books. She appears to be engaged in a conversation or interview, as indicated by her facial expressions and the presence of subtitles in Spanish. The subtitles translate to phrases such as "pero lo dudo," "Luego me fui a un internado en Inglaterra," "a un centro de los cuáqueros, que son cristianos," "Los cuáqueros siempre han creído que es muy importante que las mujeres estudien," and "igual que los hombres, y esto a mí me benefició, me animaron mucho." These subtitles suggest that the woman is recounting her experiences, including attending a boarding school in England and a Quaker center, where she was encouraged to study, similar to men, which greatly benefited her. The setting is calm and studious, with the woman's expressions and the subtitles providing insight into her personal narrative and the values of the Quaker community.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single female speaker describing her experience attending boarding school in England. She mentions it was a "Quaker School," a part of the Christian church, and emphasizes the Quaker movement's focus on educating women, from which she benefited and received encouragement. In the background is light, gentle piano music adding a calm tone to the audio.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen that transitions to a scene in a lecture hall filled with students, where the text "Encontramos en Gran Bretaña que la Astronomía," (We found in Great Britain that Astronomy) appears at the bottom. The scene shifts to a woman in a black and white polka dot dress speaking at a podium with a model of the solar system, accompanied by the text "son atractivas, para los adolescentes," (is attractive to teenagers). A close-up of a woman in a library setting follows, with the text "pero no hablamos con los padres." (but we don't talk to the parents). The narrative continues with a man in a suit speaking, with the text "No, no quieres. ¿Por qué quieres hacer eso?" (No, you don't want to. Why do you want to do that?). The scene then shows a group of people, including children, with the text "Se nos olvida convencer a los padres también," (We forget to convince the parents too). The video concludes with credits listing various contributors and sources, including "Entrevista Antonia M. Varela," "Asesora de contenido Nayra Rodríguez Eugenio," and "Cámara y post-producción Inés Bonet," among others. The final frame displays the text "ARCHIVO" followed by a list of institutions and organizations, such as "Instituto de Astrofísica de Canarias (IAC)" and "NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center Conceptual Image Lab."
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a calm, reasoned female voice discussing the shortage of people studying physics in Britain. She notes the appeal of astronomy and particle physics to teenagers, but points out a mistake of not including parents in the discussion. The woman expresses the potential scenario where a child wants to be a scientist, but the parents disapprove in a dismissive tone, preferring the child pursue business studies. She concludes that this omission is a bad mistake. While she is speaking, there is light instrumental music playing in the background, in a classical style, that produces a gentle and reflective mood.
